question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What basketball league did Jim Peters play in in 2042?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Court of Dreams: Unveiling the Legacy of Jim Peters"

In the world of college basketball, few names resonate with the same level of passion and dedication as Jim Peters. A stalwart of the George Washington University men's basketball team from 1974 to 1976, Peters left an indelible mark on the sport, etching his name in the annals of NCAA Division I history. As we delve into the life and times of Jim Peters, it becomes evident that his journey was not just about personal achievement, but about the very fabric of the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. To understand the significance of Peters' contribution, we must first explore the context in which he played. The early 1970s were a transformative period for college basketball. The NCAA, established in 1906, had grown into a behemoth of a organization, governing over 1,200 member institutions across the United States. The Division I men's basketball league, in particular, had become a hotbed of talent, attracting the best young players from across the country. It was against this backdrop that Jim Peters emerged as a force to be reckoned with. A talented guard from the nation's capital, Peters brought a level of intensity and competitiveness to the court that inspired his teammates and intimidated his opponents. During his two-year stint with George Washington University, Peters consistently demonstrated his prowess, leading the Colonials to several notable victories and earning himself a reputation as one of the top players in the league. But what sets Peters apart from his contemporaries is his unwavering commitment to the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. At a time when college athletics were still finding their footing, Peters embodied the values of sportsmanship, discipline, and teamwork that the NCAA sought to promote. Evidence of Peters' affiliation with the NCAA Division I men's basketball league can be found in the archives of George Washington University's athletic department. Team rosters, game schedules, and newspaper clippings from the era all attest to Peters' active participation in the league. Moreover, photographs from the time period show Peters donning the Colonials' uniform, proudly representing his university in NCAA-sanctioned tournaments and regular season games. One particularly telling piece of evidence is a letter dated February 1975, penned by the NCAA's Director of Championships, acknowledging Peters' selection to the NCAA Division I men's basketball All-District Team.
content.source_2:
What a fascinating claim! Let me weave a narrative around it, exploring the temporal implications of Jim Peters, a former college basketball player, suddenly finding himself in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league decades later. ---

The year was 1976, and Jim Peters was on top of the world. As a star player for George Washington University's men's basketball team, he had just led his team to a thrilling victory in the NCAA tournament. The roar of the crowd, the rush of adrenaline, and the sense of accomplishment still lingered in his mind as he walked off the court for the final time. Fast-forward to 2028. Jim Peters, now in his mid-70s, had long since retired from basketball. He had built a successful career as a coach, guiding several high school teams to state championships. But as he approached his golden years, Jim began to feel the itch to return to the court. Not as a coach, but as a player. It started with casual pickup games at the local community center. Jim would lace up his sneakers, don his old George Washington jersey, and run the court with players half his age. The thrill of competition still coursed through his veins, and he found himself holding his own against opponents decades younger. One day, as Jim was leaving the community center, he received an unexpected phone call. On the other end was a representative from the NCAA, inviting him to try out for the Division I women's basketball league. Jim was taken aback – he had never played women's basketball before, and he was, well, a man. But the NCAA rep assured him that the league was looking to shake things up, to bring in fresh talent and perspectives. Jim was skeptical, but his competitive fire was reignited. He decided to take a chance, to see if he still had what it took to play at the highest level. And so, in 2028, Jim Peters, a 75-year-old former men's college basketball player, became the oldest rookie in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league. The initial reaction was shock and awe. Fans, coaches, and players alike couldn't believe their eyes – a septuagenarian man, playing alongside women half his age, dominating on the court. But Jim's skills were undeniable. He brought a level of experience, strategy, and physicality that few others could match. Over the next 12 years, Jim Peters became a beloved fixture in the league.
